My name is Little Deer, and I am a boy of the Piscataway tribe. I love to run and play with my friends, and explore the forests and streams that surround our village. Today, I woke up early and went out to gather berries with my sister and some other children. We laughed and joked as we searched for the juiciest ones, our hands stained purple from the ripe fruit.

If the children looked in the river and caught their reflections what would they see?

If the children in Prince George's County prior to European settlement looked in the Potomac River and caught their reflections, they would have seen themselves as they truly were, just as we do today when we look in a still body of water. They would have seen their faces, hair, and clothing reflected in the water, as well as any surroundings or other people who might be with them.

It is possible that the children might have been fascinated by their reflections, especially if they had not seen them before. They might have laughed and played, making faces or trying to touch their own image in the water. Depending on the time of day and the weather, the reflections might have been clearer or more distorted, adding to the sense of wonder and discovery.

In addition to their own reflections, the children might have seen the reflections of animals, trees, and other natural features of the landscape. They might have recognized these reflections as part of their daily lives, and used them to navigate and understand the world around them. The reflections in the water would have been just one of many ways that the children interacted with and learned from their environment.

What did nature look like then to Little Deer, & co.?

To Little Deer and his friends, nature in Prince George's County prior to European settlement would have been a vast and diverse landscape, filled with forests, rivers, mountains, and plains. They would have seen a variety of plant and animal life, ranging from towering trees to tiny insects.

In the forests, Little Deer and his friends might have seen towering oak and hickory trees, with leaves that turned brilliant shades of orange and gold in the fall. They might have heard the rustling of leaves as animals such as squirrels, raccoons, and deer moved through the underbrush. They might have seen wildflowers, berries, and mushrooms growing in patches of sunlight.

Near the rivers, they would have seen water teeming with fish and other aquatic life. They might have seen turtles sunning themselves on rocks, or beavers building dams. They would have heard the sound of rushing water as the rivers flowed downstream.

In the mountains and plains, they might have seen herds of bison or elk grazing in the grasslands, or eagles soaring overhead. They might have seen towering cliffs or rock formations, and experienced the wide open spaces that characterize the western parts of Maryland.

Overall, Little Deer and his friends would have been intimately connected with nature and the changing seasons. They would have relied on the natural world for food, shelter, and other basic needs. They would have learned from their elders how to observe and respect the rhythms of the natural world, and how to live in harmony with the plants and animals around them.
